description:
Paramisgurnus dabryanus, commonly known as the Chinese loach or Dabry's gudgeon, is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the family Cobitidae. It is native to rivers and lakes in China, including the Yangtze and Pearl River basins.

Paramisgurnus dabryanus is a small, elongated fish with a cylindrical body and a rounded snout. It typically grows to a length of around 8-12 centimeters (3-4.7 inches). The fish has four pairs of barbels around its mouth, which it uses to search for food, such as small invertebrates, algae, and detritus, on the bottom of the water bodies it inhabits.

The species is characterized by its unique morphological features, including the presence of a pair of pelvic fins and the absence of a lateral line system. It has a dark-colored body with a pale belly and distinctive dark markings or bands along the sides.

Paramisgurnus dabryanus is an important component of the freshwater ecosystems it occupies, serving as a food source for larger predatory fish and contributing to the overall biodiversity of its native habitats. The species is also of interest to aquarium hobbyists and has been successfully kept and bred in captivity.
